header.title: Black Rûna: Being the Shorter Works of STEPHEN EDRED FLOWERS Produced for the Order of the Trapezoid of the Temple of Set (1985-1989)

central_thesis: The central thesis of 'Black Rûna' is to present an anthology of Stephen Edred Flowers' contributions to the Order of the Trapezoid's journal, 'Runes,' from 1985-1989. These works systematically explore and articulate the philosophical and operative aspects of the Northern tradition of magic and initiation from a distinct Left-Hand Path perspective. The book aims to clarify the ideological and magical world of the Order of the Trapezoid, emphasizing individual self-deification, independent evolution, and the willed alteration of the universe, while also defining 'RÛNA' as 'A Sense of the Hidden' – an arcanic principle foundational to the Order's work.

structure_content.summary: This section outlines the purpose of the book as an anthology of contributions to the Order of the Trapezoid from 1985-1989. It details the author's involvement with the Temple of Set and the Order, including the founding of 'The Order of the Shining Trapezoid.' Key philosophical distinctions are drawn between the objective and subjective universes, and the Right-Hand Path (union with the cosmos) versus the Left-Hand Path (individual self-deification and independence) are clearly defined. The author also provides precise definitions for White Magic (union-oriented) and Black Magic (self-oriented, independence-seeking). The concept of 'RÛNA' as 'A Sense of the Hidden' and an arcanic principle is introduced.

This article explores the mystery of the Graal, hypothesizing that the true Graal is not the traditional chalice but a hidden object within its base, possibly a meteoric trapezohedron. It links this to the 'philosophers' stone' and the 'heathen script' that Graal-Knights read. The trapezoid is presented as a symbol and actual mechanism for essential nourishment and ecstasy, with the power residing in its shape and interaction with consciousness rather than its substance.

structure_content.chapter_title: On the Way of Wotan and the Left-Hand Path (1985)
structure_content.summary: This chapter defines the Left-Hand Path by its principle of non-union or 'continuing, (dynamic) independent evolution,' which is the meaning of Walhalla. It contrasts this with the Right-Hand Path's goal of terminal union and absorption. The Odian path (Way of Wotan) is identified as the sole historical example of a national Left-Hand Path, detailing the three destinations for the souls of the dead in Germanic belief: Hel (static reabsorption), rebirth to Midhgardhr (continued evolution), and Walhalla (Einherjar – independent existence).

Analyzing William Mortensen's 'The Command to Look,' the author reframes its photographic principles as a foundation for Black Magical practice ('Magia Technica'). The CTL formula is presented as three-fold: IMPACT (psychically coercive shapes like diagonals, s-curves, triangles, and dominant masses/trapezoids), SUBJECT INTEREST (compelling themes like sex, sentiment, wonder), and PARTICIPATION (geometrical alignments guiding the viewer's attention). These principles are applied to Lesser Black Magic (personal presentation) and Greater Black Magic (impressing images on subjective/objective universes), noting its application in the Seal of the Order of the Trapezoid.

This article outlines a 'runology of the future,' synthesizing traditional runic and Trapezoidal Principles. It discusses individual runes from the Elder Futhark, assigning them esoteric principles and often linking them to concepts central to the Order of the Trapezoid. The aim is to go beyond traditional runic uses, illuminating obscure angles of the Trapezoid and fostering unique power and wisdom within the Order.

The author examines the psychological impact of runic shapes, attributing their engaging nature to a predominance of obtuse and acute angles, which attract and hold attention. This is contrasted with the 'flat, lifeless' appearance of Roman capitals with their right angles and curves. This visual characteristic is linked to the 'Command to Look' and the runes' inherent ability to convey mystery and power.

structure_content.chapter_title: Graal Mythos in Old English Runes? (1986)
structure_content.summary: This piece speculates on the Graal-Mythos within Old English runic tradition. It posits that the juxtaposition of three specific runes – 'calc' (chalice), 'stân' (stone), and 'gâr' (spear) – in an 11th-century manuscript, represents an esoteric understanding of the Graal as a chalice-stone-spear complex. The spear is further identified with Wotan's Gungnir, suggesting a Germanic, heathen origin for this mythical complex, distinct from later Christianized versions.

The article traces the 'peace sign' of the 1960s to runic origins, specifically the inverted Algiz/Yr rune, which symbolized 'death' in early 20th-century esoteric runology (e.g., Guido von List's system). It highlights the sign's use by anti-Nazi Leftists and Russian propagandists as a symbol of death against their German targets, demonstrating its deployment in psychological warfare and its inherent 'Command to Look' due to its deep psychic resonance.

This work explores the complementary relationship between Wotan (Woden) and Set. Wotan is depicted as the archetypal magical hero and Initiate, embodying the will to power and knowledge, acquiring inspiration through initiatory processes. Set is defined as the crystalline Form of pure Self-Consciousness, the Principle of Isolate Intelligence, which is a prerequisite for all other god-forms and consciousness. The two are complementary, with Set enabling Wotan's self-realization and the understanding of the Runes, illustrating the 'Gift of Set' as the infusion of this Form into man.

The article presents historical evidence of Germanic presence and magical exchange in Egypt during the Roman Age, citing an ostrakon mentioning 'Waluburg sibyl of the Semnones.' This figure is linked to the traditional Walpurgisnacht and the Æon of Satan/Set, suggesting a historical path for Germanic magicians to learn and adapt Setian principles from Greco-Egyptian occultism, subsequently reintroducing them into European culture.

This chapter examines German Expressionist cinema (Schauerfilme, 1919-1933) as a root for the Order of the Trapezoid's heritage, influenced by Anton LaVey. It focuses on Albin Grau (Frater Pacitus), a set designer for films like 'Nosferatu,' who had deep connections to the German occult scene (Pansophical Lodge, Fraternitas Saturni). The analysis suggests that these films' portrayals of Black Masses and magical practices reflected actual occult workings of the era, forming a 'Magical stream' later accessed by LaVey.

structure_content.chapter_title: Austin Osman Spare and the Track of the Trapezoid (1987)
structure_content.summary: The article analyzes the magical artistry of Austin Osman Spare, particularly his sigilization techniques and 'Neither-Neither theory,' which explored 'inbetweenness' between polarities. It argues that Spare's work with n-dimensional geometries and his concept of the 'Obscene Angle' align with the emerging Trapezoidal current, even if he didn't explicitly use the terminology. His explorations of extra-dimensional reality are seen as proto-Trapezoidal, paralleling concepts like LaVey's 'Elektrische Vorspiele.'

This article discusses the application of Lesser Black Magic in National Socialism, framing its cultic rites and mass rallies as techniques for forging a 'general will' and manipulating the 'Volk.' It parallels these methods with LaVey's 'Die elektrischen Vorspiele' and the Yezidis' Seven Towers of Satan, highlighting how ritualistically shaped space, motion, color, sound, and spoken word were used to influence human events. The analysis distinguishes this practical manipulation from sensationalized 'occult Nazism.'

structure_content.chapter_title: A Root of the 'Occult Nazi Mythos' Review of The Occult Causes of the Present War (1987)
structure_content.summary: This is a critical review of Lewis Spence's 'The Occult Causes of the Present War.' Flowers argues that Spence's book, published during WWII, is primarily wartime propaganda, characterized by circular logic and racial biases. While acknowledging its role in establishing the 'Occult Nazi Mythos,' the review dismisses its claims as lacking real information and serving a polemic against Germanic culture, ultimately deeming it suitable for 'the curiosity cabinet of history.'

Exploring 'Magia Technica,' this article details mechanical contraptions used in magic. It mentions Nikola Tesla's devices and Wilhelm Reich's Orgone Energy Accumulator as examples of technology with paranormal applications. The core focus is on historical magical machines: the 'prognomètre' (a divining machine) and the 'Tepaphon' (an electrical apparatus for remote killing/healing) from German occult traditions like the FOGC and Fraternitas Saturni. These are presented as precursors to the 'elektrikal' rites of the Order of the Trapezoid and inspirations for 'Mad Lab' scenes in Expressionist films.

This article distinguishes between two types of Old Norse magic: 'galdr' (vocal utterances, symbolic acts, straightforward use of will) and 'seidhr' (trance states, sometimes sexual, considered 'shameful' or unmanly). Runic magic is positioned as a primary tool for magicians to objectify their will in graphic form. The author notes that runes were used almost exclusively for magical ends in early periods and that the term 'rún' itself means 'secret' or 'mystery.' The discussion extends to 'galdrabækur' (books of magic) and 'galdrastafir' (magical signs).

This piece re-examines 'Nazi occultism,' aiming to provide a more accurate perspective beyond sensationalism. Flowers defines Black Magic philosophically as the pursuit of one's own will, leading to self-deification against the 'natural cosmic order.' He argues that National Socialism can be understood as a form of Black Magic, aiming to evolve a 'god-like race of supermen' through a collective rebellion against nature. The article contrasts Rudolf Steiner's 'right occultism' (universal-human aims) with 'left occultism' (particular aims), linking Ariosophy and NS to the latter, thereby enriching the understanding of 'evil' within this context.

structure_content.chapter_title: On the Choice of a Human Sacrifice... (1989)
structure_content.summary: The article clarifies the concept of 'sacrifice,' distinguishing between Indo-European practices (a gift to gods, convivial meal, painless) and Semitic/Aztec traditions (payment, expiation, often involving human sacrifice). It aligns Anton LaVey's concept of 'human sacrifice' – magically, not physically, directed at those who harm the practitioner – with traditional Germanic views on retribution against criminals and enemies. The author critiques the historical misattribution of Semitic sacrificial practices to European paganism by Christian writers.
A comprehensive list of books and articles cited or relevant to the topics discussed in 'Black Rûna,' covering works on occultism, German history, runology, magic, and related esoteric subjects.

This section provides information for potential members of the Temple of Set and the Order of the Trapezoid, outlining the prerequisite of attaining the Grade of Adept within the Temple. It also explains that 'The Seal of Rûna' on the book's cover is the personal magical insignia of Dr. Stephen Edred Flowers, emblematic of the V°, with its full ramifications part of the inner teachings.

key_concepts.definition: The title refers to two things: 'Black' denotes the Left-Hand Path character of the Work, and 'Rûna' is a reference to the Word RÛNA, which signifies 'A Sense of the Hidden' – the Arcanic Principle implicit in the core depth of the sentient Self and beyond the cosmos, driving inquiry and discovery of the unknown. It is the principle of the Hidden itself.

A spiritual and magical path characterized by non-union or 'continuing, (dynamic) independent evolution.' It is psychecentric (soul/self-centered), focusing on individual self-deification, empowerment, and isolation of consciousness to ever more perfect levels, rejecting submission to external cosmic or divine order.

A spiritual path opposed to the LHP, dictating 'union' or terminal, static, dependent non-evolution. It is theocentric ('other-centered'), aiming for submission to universal reality (God or Nature), leading to the annihilation of the individual self and becoming one with the cosmic order.

A methodology for the exercise of independence from the universe and the pursuit of self-oriented aims. It is seen as more purely magical, using the individual will as primary to make the universe conform to its bidding, rather than harmonizing with a universal pattern.

A methodology for the promotion of union with the universe and the pursuit of aims in harmony with those of the universe. Structurally, it has much in common with religion, where the human community attempts to harmonize its behavior with a universal paradigm.

A magical concept and body within the Temple of Set, characterized as an order of knighthood pledged to strict personal honor and faithfulness to the quest for the Grail. It is defined as the gate to psychecentric immortality beyond physical death, focusing on the conscious refinement and exercise of the Will for the self, soul, or psyche.

The application of electrical, mechanical, or technological apparati for magical purposes, going beyond traditional elemental technologies (fire, air, earth, water). Examples include the Tesla Coil, Orgone Energy Accumulator, prognomètre, and Tepaphon, influencing events in the objective universe.

A three-fold formula for commanding attention, adapted from William Mortensen's work on photography for Black Magical application. It consists of: (1) IMPACT (shapes/patterns signalling DANGER), (2) SUBJECT INTEREST (compelling themes like sex, sentiment, wonder), and (3) PARTICIPATION (geometrical alignments guiding attention). It is used to influence consciousness on an unconscious level.

Hypothesized as the 'true Graal,' seen as a lump of meteoric substance cut and polished into a specific geometric shape. Its power lies in its form and how consciousness interacts with it, rather than its substance, used as a 'shew stone' for obtaining visions and Essential nourishment, allowing one to 'read heathen script.'

The crystalline Form of pure Self-Consciousness, or the Principle of Isolate Intelligence. It is dynamic, coherent, and ordered, existing in a perpetual state of separation from the organic/mechanical universe. Set is considered the prerequisite of all Forms of consciousness and god-forms, enabling the clear perception of Self as separate.

The archetypal magician and questing hero in Germanic tradition. He embodies all extremes and seeks to synthesize them, representing the pure suprarational will to power, knowledge, and eternal becoming. Wotan acquires inspiration and understanding through an initiatory process (e.g., Runic Initiation), making him an exemplary model of The Initiate.

The purposeful reversal or embrace of conventional normatives and symbols of 'evil,' 'impurity,' or 'darkness' to gain inner independence. Practitioners go 'against the grain' of culturally conditioned norms, seeking a 'higher law' of reality based on knowledge and power, while upholding rigorous ethical standards based on understanding.

An Old Norse type of magic characterized by volitive symbolic behavior, typically involving vocal utterances ('gala' – to make sound of crow/raven) and visible signs. It is a more straightforward use of the magician's will to directly impress upon the environment.

An Old Norse type of magic that developed a reputation for being 'shameful' or 'unmanly.' It often involved the loss of conscious control and the induction of trance states, and sometimes sexual activity. Freyja taught Odhinn this art, distinguishing it from 'galdr'.

The popular 'peace sign' of the 1960s is traced to runic origins, specifically the inverted Algiz/Yr rune. In early 20th-century esoteric runology (e.g., Guido von List), this symbol explicitly meant 'death' (in contrast to the upright Algiz/Man rune meaning 'life'). It was used in psychological warfare by anti-Nazis and Russians as a symbol of death against their German targets.

practical_system.description: The system described in 'Black Rûna' is rooted in the Left-Hand Path, emphasizing individual self-deification, independent evolution, and the willed alteration of the universe (both objective and subjective). Black Magic, as defined, is self-oriented and seeks independence from cosmic and natural laws, actively making the universe conform to the magician's will. It integrates Setian philosophy (the Principle of Isolate Intelligence) as foundational for individual consciousness, with Germanic runic traditions adapted into a 'runology of the future' to serve these Trapezoidal Principles. The system incorporates Magia Technica, utilizing modern and historical mechanical/electrical apparati for magical effects, and applies principles of psychological manipulation (e.g., 'The Command to Look') to command attention, influence others, and shape collective consciousness for Greater Black Magic.
tools: Conscious Will: The paramount force in Black Magic, used to initiate and direct all magical operations and transformations.

Trapezohedron: Functions as a 'shew stone' or the 'true Graal,' a physical form (possibly meteoric) whose shape and interaction with consciousness provide visions and 'Essential nourishment' for 'reading heathen writing.'
Runic Symbols: Used as a 'psychologically engaging script' and a system of esoteric principles to objectify the magician's will and effect changes in the environment.
Geometrical Sigils and Patterns: Employed according to 'The Command to Look' for impact, subject interest, and guiding participation to manipulate attention and perception.

Electrical/Mechanical Apparati (Magia Technica): Including devices like the Tesla Coil, Orgone Energy Accumulator, the prognomètre (divining machine), and the Tepaphon (for remote harming/healing), used to project will and traverse dimensions.

Ritualistic Elements: Shaped space, specific motions, colors, sounds (music), and spoken words (chants, invocations) used in collective and individual workings for mass manipulation and focused intent.

Conceptual Frameworks: Distinct understandings of the objective/subjective universe, Left-Hand/Right-Hand Path, Set/Wotan, and definitions of magic itself, providing the philosophical lens for practice.
rituals: Trapezoidal Workings: Aimed at individual self-refinement and psychecentric immortality within the Order of the Trapezoid.

Command to Look Applications: Utilizing specific shapes, patterns, and themes (IMPACT, SUBJECT INTEREST, PARTICIPATION) to psychically coerce attention, influence perceptions in Lesser Black Magic (e.g., personal presentation) and impress willed images onto subjective and objective universes for Greater Black Magic.
Runic Workings: Employing runes as a 'runology of the future,' integrating Trapezoidal Principles beyond traditional uses to generate power and wisdom through their forms and esoteric associations.

Magie und Manipulation (LBM): Implementing cultic rites, mass rallies, and psychological warfare (e.g., as seen in National Socialism analysis) to forge a 'general will' and influence collective human events by leveraging 'psychological resonance.'

Magical Human Sacrifice: A conceptual practice (not physical) directed at those who harm the practitioner, aligning with traditional Germanic retribution and LaVeyan principles of targeting enemies through magical means to rebalance cosmic order.
Initiatory Processes: Stages of magical evolution designed by the magician's will to attain enlightened, independently existing intellect and relative immortality.

relevant_quotes.text: Black Rûna is designed to allow the general public some access to the genuine ideological and magical world of the Order of the Trapezoid— which I hope will dispel much of the inflammatory nonsense that has been written about this noble Order in the tabloid-type press.

The subjective universe is capable of a full spectrum of possibilities which range from virtually absolute precisions to almost total delusion because it is not bound by natural laws. The focus or epicenter of this non-natural subjective universe is equated with human consciousness, or soul, or self.
Magic is the willed application of symbolic methods to cause or prevent changes in the universe by means of symbolic acts of communication with paranormal factors.

In a precise sense the distinction between White and Black Magic is that White Magic is a methodology for the promotion of union with the universe and pursuing aims in harmony with those of the universe, while Black Magic is such a methodology for the exercise of independence from the universe and pursuing self-oriented aims.

This present book is called Black Rûna. This name refers to two things: the word "Black" refers to the Left-Hand Path character of the Work contained herein, but the word "Rûna" is a reference to the Word RÛNA, which was Uttered by me on December 20 (Mother Night) 1988. The Utterance was finally officially Recognized by the Temple of Set on July 13, 1990.
The power is in the way consciousness interacts with form, not in the thing or substance itself. But there may be more to this particular substance than we know right now...
The first principle of the Left-Hand Path is non-union— or, more correctly and positively: continuing, (dynamic) independent evolution. This is the meaning of Walhalla.

The Form of Set is the crystalline Form of pure Self-Consciousness [or the Principle of Isolate Intelligence]. The Form, although dynamic, is coherent and ordered within itSelf and remains in a perpetual state of separation from the organic/mechanical universe.

National Socialism can perhaps be called a form of Black Magic in that it set about—against the grain of Nature—to evolve itself into a higher, more powerful god-like race of supermen based on particular national characteristics.
The true meaning of being able to "read heathen writing" on the facets of the Graal-Stone, or Hail-Stone.

critical_analysis.relevance: 'Black Rûna' is highly relevant for understanding the esoteric foundations and practical applications within the Temple of Set's Left-Hand Path current. It offers a unique synthesis of Germanic runic traditions, Setian philosophy (Isolate Intelligence), and modern magical theory, such as 'Magia Technica.' The book provides deep insights into the operative distinction between White and Black Magic, emphasizing self-deification, antinomianism, and the willed alteration of consciousness and external reality. Its exploration of historical occult figures like Austin Osman Spare and Anton LaVey, along with its controversial analysis of National Socialism as a form of Black Magic (focusing on manipulative techniques rather than racial dogmas), positions it as a significant contribution to both the practical study of occultism and the academic critical analysis of esoteric influences in history and politics. The text's focus on structured, willed magical acts makes it particularly valuable for practitioners seeking to deepen their understanding of psychecentric magic.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience consists of members and initiates of the Temple of Set and the Order of the Trapezoid, or individuals deeply interested in their specific philosophical and magical current. It also appeals to academic researchers in Western Esotericism, Left-Hand Path studies, Runology, and the history of 20th-century occultism. Magicians interested in operative Black Magic, psychological manipulation in ritual, and innovative approaches to integrating traditional systems with modern magical technology (Magia Technica) would find significant value. The text assumes a foundational familiarity with occult concepts, historical figures, and esoteric terminology.
